{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3524523,"name":"Aysen Chong","username":"Crazehorse","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b5e925/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T06:20:33.361Z","cooked":"

Graph of applied output, current, and voltage1908×841 105 KB

We were testing our newly wired-up robot and we ran into some issues with our NEO Brushless Motors and SPARK MAXs we’ve never encountered before. We set the motor to 0.25 through REV Hardware Client, however the SparkMax is only showing 0.079 applied output. This number: 0.079 stays roughly the same regardless of how high or low we set the applied output. We believe there’s some issue between the motor and spark because the SparkMax is getting around 12 volts and 30 amps of current. We’ve checked connections between the motor and PDH and everything seems to be in order. This is happening to multiple motors/SparkMaxes on our robot but not all of them. Additionally, it’s not just one motor type it is affecting our NEO 1.1’s and NEO 550’s.

Any help would be much appreciated. Thanks!

What’s your current limit? I’m assuming that you’re hitting your current limit (30amps) so the spark limits the output to prevent exceeding that limit.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T07:21:18.254Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":31.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491331,"topic_slug":"spark-max-giving-very-low-applied-output-voltage","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60754,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/spark-max-giving-very-low-applied-output-voltage/491331/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3551913,"name":"steinra","username":"steinra","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/steinra/{size}/3823_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-09T16:21:16.193Z","cooked":"
Spaceman:

I’m assuming that you’re hitting your current limit (30amps) so the spark limits the output to prevent exceeding that limit.

Adding to this in case others stumble onit. Current limit indeed seem to limit the voltage curve from going up on the SPARK Flex as well.

These are from testing our drive system. We kept hitting intermittent spots where holding the joystick to full speed did nothing to move the bot. In logging we saw the calculated values were correct (ffVolts) but the output never went above 1 volt. This is while pulling 40 Amps where our current limits were set. This only seemed to be in certain cases where it could not start moving fast enough.

If we bounced the stick enough times it would dig out. If we left it sit for a minute it would eventually dig out and slowly accelerate with the voltage going up.

It seems to make sense why to protect the motors, but one would think it might try a little more volts a couple of times to see if it would dig out of stall condition.

We upped our current limits to 60 Amps and that seems to fix out issue.

joystick1958×712 57.3 KB

This one you can see the hold flat below 1 volt and then a move of the stick allowed it to reset and dig out.

joystick2976×704 63 KB

This one you can see the hold flat at below 1 volt and then the gradual acceleration of the voltage while the target output is held constant.

joystick3968×705 74.3 KB

Again a hold flat then a stick reset followed by a slow acceleration.

joystick4949×698 60.2 KB

This one shows how many times we had to bounce the stick to get it to slowly accelerate.

Anyone with other ideas on how to get it to apply more voltage without upping the current limits? Is this a hard firmware limit that even PID tuning on the velocity set point will not fix? We also tried with velocity setpoint as well as direct voltage setting. Both behaved the same way.
